column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/368f6bd6-7eb7-4370-9ab1-412a91861eef;"Cultural landscapes of the future: using agent-based modeling to discuss and develop the use and management of the cultural landscape of South West Devon";"";"Context: Hedgerows are typical landscape features of high environmental and cultural value that often have been sacrificed for agricultural intensification and scale enlargement. Objectives: We studied the dynamics of hedgerow quality over time in a case study area renowned for its hedgerow landscapes: South West Devon (UK) answering the following research questions: (1) how does the imperative of scale enlargement affect hedgerow quality? and (2) to what extent can cultural landscape degradation be countered by targeted policies? Methods: We applied an agent-based modeling approach
column2: parameterized with a site specific survey
column3: to explore and discuss outcomes of future landscape change with stakeholders and co-designed preferred scenarios of landscape change during a workshop. Results: Outcomes suggested that in the case-study area
column4: scale enlargement has a negative effect on hedgerow quality when agri-environment scheme subsidies (AES) are low. In contrast
column5: if the level of AES enrollment is high
column6: scale enlargement can have a positive effect on hedgerow quality
column7: as large holders are more likely to enroll for AES. Stakeholders acknowledged the need for agricultural intensification
column8: but at the same time valued biodiversity and environmental value of the landscape in South West Devon. Conclusion: Current AES are able to retain a decent hedgerow quality. With lower AES
column9: scale enlargement can have an invigorative effect on hedgerow quality as land managers of larger farms will be less likely to join AES As an addition to AES
column10: harvesting wood fuel from coppiced hedgerows appears a promising way to incentivize rejuvenating hedgerow management without governmental subsidies.";"Tieskens

column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/eeae9444-852d-4f92-8748-59b45d670efd;"Suitability analysis in a changing climate";"";"Land suitability analysis is employed to evaluate the appropriateness of land for a particular purpose whilst integrating both qualitative and quantitative inputs
column2: which can be continuous in nature. However
column3: in agricultural modelling there is often a disregard of this contiguous aspect. Therefore
column4: some parametric procedures for suitability analysis compartmentalise units into defined membership classes. This imposition of crisp boundaries neglects the continuous formations found throughout nature and overlooks differences and inherent uncertainties found in the modelling. This research will compare two approaches to suitability analysis over three differing methods. The primary approach will use an Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP)
column5: while the other approach will use a Fuzzy AHP over two methods; Fitted Fuzzy AHP and Nested Fuzzy AHP. Secondary to this
column6: each method will be assessed into how it behaves in a climate change scenario to understand and highlight the role of uncertainties in model conceptualisation and structure. Outputs and comparisons between each method
column7: in relation to area
column8: proportion of membership classes and spatial representation
column9: showed that fuzzy modelling techniques detailed a more robust and continuous output. In particular the Nested Fuzzy AHP was concluded to be more pertinent
column10: as it incorporated complex modelling techniques
column11: as well as the initial AHP framework. Through this comparison and assessment of model behaviour
column12: an evaluation of each methods predictive capacity and relevance for decision-making purposes in agricultural applications is gained.";"Romeijn

column1:
NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/553988;"Land use change and the migration geography of Greater White-fronted geese in European Russia";"";"

Large areas of agricultural land have been abandoned in European Russia since 1991
column2: triggering succession toward more wooded landscapes
column3: especially in northern regions where conditions for agriculture are more challenging. We hypothesize that this process has contributed to a southward shift by migratory Atlantic Greater White-fronted geese
column4: as stopover sites in northern Russia became progressively less suitable. To test this hypothesis
column5: we located stopover sites from information contained in 2976 ring recoveries and sightings of neck-collared geese. These records were divided into three time periods
column6: chosen to reflect major changes in the economy and land use of European Russia: 1960–1990
column8: and 2001–2013. We used a kernel density estimator grid to delineate areas surrounding 300 putative stopover sites
column9: and statistically evaluated the effects of latitude
column10: distance to nearest waterbody
column11: settlement
column12: and period on stopover site usage by geese. Our results show that over the three periods
column13: usage of the stopover sites has shifted southward
column14: indicating that Greater White-fronted geese have shifted their migration pathway
column15: with the greatest shift in the most recent period. This shift was confirmed by a highly significant squared latitude term and significant interaction term between periods. The nearest settlements showed no significant effect on stopover site usage while the nearest waterbody term was negative
column16: suggesting higher waterbody densities contributed to higher densities of stopover sites. We attribute the shift to the successional reforestation of the Russian landscape that has followed widespread land abandonment
column17:
especially that following the break-up of the former USSR.

";"Grishchenko

NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/553050;"A bird’s-eye view of recreation : improving the application of scientific knowledge and tools in collaborative decision-making processes";"";"

Natural areas are essential for species conservation and outdoor recreation. Where conservation and recreational values are under threat
column2: site managers need to take measures to protect them. Scientific knowledge and tools might help them to predict the outcomes of planned measures and create support amongst stakeholders. To be accepted by all stakeholders the knowledge and tools must possess three attributes credibility
column3: salience and legitimacy. In this PhD thesis existing scientific knowledge and tools were made context-specific and local measures were related to regional conservation targets for different study areas in the UK
column4: Netherlands and France. The process of integrating site-specific data and local knowledge in the tools helps stakeholders explain their view of the local context and increases the salience and legitimacy of the knowledge and tools while their credibility is maintained. This leads to a co-learning process between recreation stakeholders
column5: conservation stakeholders
column6:
managers and scientists where measures are supported by all parties involved.

";"Pouwels

column1:
NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/551798;"War-induced displacement: Hard choices in land governance";"";"

Civil war and violence often force large numbers of people to leave their lands. Multiple waves of displacement and (partial) return generate complex overlapping claims that are not easily solved. As people return to their regions of origin-sometimes after decades-they tend to find their land occupied by other settlers
column2: some of whom hold legal entitlements. In the places of arrival
column3: displaced people affect other people's access as they seek to turn their temporary entitlements into more definite claims. The overlapping claims related to displacement pose serious dilemmas to land governance
column4: which existing land laws and land governance institutions are not well-equipped to deal with. This paper outlines the main challenges for land governance as a first step to move the debate forward. The paper summarises the key challenges around three tensions: first
column5: between short term conflict resolution and structural solutions; second
column6: between state and customary/community-based governance; and finally
column7:
between principles (such as the right to return or restitution) and acknowledgement of the new situation.

";"Haar

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/550479;"The determinants of recent soybean expansion in Mato Grosso
column3: catalyzes or constraints land use change in the Brazilian agricultural frontier is a condition for effective policy design at the local level
column4: which in turn might have implications for food production
column5: environmental conservation and greenhouse gas emissions worldwide. We analyzed the process of agricultural expansion observed in the state of Mato Grosso
column6: the country's largest agricultural producer
column7: by mapping and quantifying the incorporation of new farming areas and the conversion of existing ones into mechanized soybean fields at the farm-level. Through statistical modelling we also investigated the influence of key economic
column8: biophysical
column9: environmental and logistics variables on this process while accounting for recent changes in the Brazilian environmental legislation. We found that the area converted to soybean production increased almost 1.5 million hectares between 2009 and 2013
column10: more than 70% of which in farms that already had some soybean in previous years. By comparing the explanatory power of eight regression models involving different groups of variables
column11: we found that soybean expansion is strongly associated with the presence of other soybean fields and warehouses within 50-100 km. The model with the largest explanatory power suggests that soybean expansion is also likely to occur in areas of high conservation value. Finally
column12:
the sensitivity of soybean expansion to soybean prices indicated the potential for further agricultural growth in Mato Grosso while highlighting how crucial smart logistics investments are for regional development with environmental protection.

";"Melo Celidonio

This thesis investigates the communicative qualities of visual landscape design representations. The main subjects of inquiry were (1) visual design representations in their many forms and appearances; (2) the meanings that are attributed to
column3: those representations by designers
column4: planners
column5: and project stakeholders; (3) the participatory planning and design processes of the multifunctional flood defence landscape projects wherein those representations are used. The meaning-making processes of visual design representations are conceptualized as a relation between the semiotic complexity of images
column6: interpretive habits of stakeholders
column7: and visual discourse of design producers. The shaping of participatory planning and design processes by design representations is categorized into a typology of nine semiotic qualities. This thesis suggests a way of looking at visual representations and organizing planning and design processes that enables planners and designers
column8: as process facilitators
column9: to determine the most appropriate communicative strategy at a specific moment
column10:
for specific participants.

column1:
NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/517003;"Beyond argumentation: a practice-based approach to environmental policy";"";"

We propose that a practice-based approach to environmental policy can help consolidate theoretical understanding of and empirical focus on practices in IPA. Doing so counteracts a tendency to privilege knowledge and discourse in IPA and environmental policy analysis. We draw on multiple strands of practice theory to inform three sensitising concepts: situated agency
column3:
and performativity. These concepts provide the analytical tools to investigate how social order and social change originate from the entanglement of meaning and action in practice. We illustrate these concepts by applying them to practices of community forest management in the countries of Ethiopia and Tanzania. Our analysis suggests that a practice-based approach is able to offer nuanced and empirically grounded accounts of political struggles and democratic practices. Its potential is especially strong in cases where policy-making and policy ideas and outcomes are less clearly linked to argumentative processes. We conclude by arguing for further inclusion and consolidation of practice-based approaches within the tradition of interpretive policy analysis.

";"Behagel
column4: Jelle Hendrik

column1: NARCIS:ut:oai:ris.utwente.nl:publications/297b0a28-d828-4ad5-9532-021d99381ef7;"Towards Responsible Consolidation of Customary Lands: A Research Synthesis";"";"The use of land consolidation on customary lands has been limited
column2: though land fragmentation persists. Land fragmentation on customary lands has two main causes—the nature of the customary land tenure system
column3: and the somewhat linked agricultural system. Since attempts to increase food productivity on customary lands have involved fertilisation and mechanisation on the small and scattered farmlands
column4: these approaches have fallen short of increasing food productivity. A study to develop a responsible approach to land consolidation on customary lands using a design research approach is undertaken and reported here. Based on a comparative study
column5: it is found that three factors inhibit the development of a responsible land consolidation approach on customary lands—the coverage of a land administration system
column6: a land valuation approach
column7: and a land reallocation approach the fits the customary land tenure system. To fill these gaps
column8: firstly
column9: this study developed the participatory land administration that brought together traditional land administration approaches with emerging bottom-up approaches
column10: as well as technological advances that drive these approaches together with the growing societal needs. Secondly
column11: a valuation approach was developed to enable the comparison of the farmlands in rural areas that are without land markets. Finally
column12: a land reallocation approach was developed based on the political
column13: economic and social
column14: as well as technical and legal characteristics of rural customary farmlands. This study concludes that though the land consolidation strategy developed is significantly able to reduce land fragmentation
column15: both physical and land tenure
column16: the local customs are an obstruction to the technical processes to achieve the best form of farmland structures.";"Asiama

column1:
NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/566032;"Between biodiversity conservation and sustainable forest management – A multidisciplinary assessment of the emblematic Białowieża Forest case";"";"

The tension between biodiversity conservation and multipurpose forest management may lead to conflicts. An internationally prominent example is the Białowieża Forest Massif (BFM)
column2: an extensive forest complex with high levels of naturalness. We apply a systematic
column3: multidisciplinary assessment process to review empirical evidence on different dimensions of the BFM conflict. While there is broad consensus that this forest massif is an exceptional place worth conserving and that a way forward is a zonation system combining conservation with management
column4: exactly how this should be done has yet to be agreed upon. Our assessment shows that the key reasons for the BFM controversy go beyond the availability of knowledge on the ecological status of the BFM and include: 1) evidence stemming from different sources
column5: which is often contradictory and prone to different interpretations; 2) knowledge gaps
column6: particularly with regard to socio-economic drivers and beneficiaries as well as uncertainties about future trends; 3) fundamentally different values and priorities among stakeholder groups
column7: resulting in power struggles
column8: and an overall lack of trust. We conclude that evidence-based knowledge alone is insufficient to cope with complex conservation conflicts. While more evidence may help assess the consequences of decisions
column9: the actual management decisions depend on different actors' worldviews
column10: which are rooted in their professional identities and power
column11:
and their political and legal realities. This calls for conflict management through a well-organized participatory process organized and supervised by a body deemed legitimate by the groups involved.

";"Blicharska
column12: M.

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/538265;"Reading landscape design representations as an interplay of validity
column2: readability and interactivity: a framework for visual content analysis";"";"Considering the importance of visual representations for communication between stakeholders in landscape planning and design processes
column3: the authors identify a lack of critical visual research methods supportive of the disciplines involved. As part of such a method
column4: they have developed an analytical framework based on semiotic and iconographic theory that enables a visual content analysis and iconographic interpretation of landscape design representations. Two projects from Rebuild by Design
column5: a participatory transdisciplinary design competition organized in the New York City area after hurricane Sandy
column6: were analysed to demonstrate this framework. The article presents a semiotic vocabulary based on four categories: medium
column7: mode
column8: formulation and knowledge with which to ‘read’
column9: discuss and potentially create design representations. This enables a syntactic analysis for assessing the semiotic complexity of design representations in terms of validity
column10: readability and interactivity. This assessment enables further qualitative study of the production and interpretation of landscape design representations in practice.";"Raaphorst

column1:
NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/558610;"Soil as a basis to create enabling conditions for transitions towards sustainable land management as a key to achieve the SDGs by 2030";"";"

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) can be grouped into three domains
column3: the social domain and the economic domain. These different layers influence each other; hence sustainable progress in the economic layer cannot be achieved without good progress in the two other layers. To achieve the SDGs
column4: transitions in the current system are needed and actions should be taken that support transitions and contribute to short term needs and long term (global) goals. Therefore
column5: it is necessary to have knowledge of transitions and understand the different phases of transition. In this paper we discuss the key role of the soil-water system in these transitions and the achievement of the SDGs by 2030. The increasing pressure on land calls for multi-use of land and for the restoration of degraded land. Healthy soils and healthy land are the basic conditions for the successful implementation and realization of the SDGs. To enable a sustainable management of the soil and water system a transition approach is a prerequisite. In the X-curve used to describe transitions
column6: soil and land stakeholders are given a framework
column7: which provides perspective for action
column8: specifically for science and governance stakeholders in each phase of the transition. This framework can provide the required intensive guidance to (1) analyze the impact of provided incentives
column9: (2) identify new reference points in the transition and (3) stimulate transition catalysts
column10: and (iv) innovate by testing cutting edge policy instruments in close cooperation with society. The key to make the necessary transitions and realize the SDGs by 2030 lies in the intensive guidance to combining initiatives
column11: steering knowledge flows and continuously assessing the stage of the transition
column12:
in order to plan specific steps needed to progress in the transition framework. Both scientist and policy makers have an important role in this guidance.

";"Visser

column1:
NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/538541;"Does property rights integrity improve tenure security? Evidence from China's forest reform";"";"

The purpose of this paper is to examine the impact of land property rights integrity
column3: mortgage rights
column4: and transfer rights
column5: on household perceptions of long-term tenure security in China. To this end
column6: we establish a theoretical framework that links China's collective forest tenure reforms undertaken since 2003 to property rights integrity and two sources of tenure (in)security based on property rights theory: forestland reallocation and expropriation. Probit models are applied in the empirical analysis to household data collected in Jiangxi province in 2011 and 2013. The results indicate that household perceptions of tenure insecurity resulting from forestland reallocation expectations are affected by transfer rights
column7: whereas household perceptions of insecurity resulting from forestland expropriation expectations are not affected by forestland rights. We thus suggest that it is crucial for policymakers to identify the sources of local property rights insecurity before they take steps to strengthen land tenure security. This paper contributes to the available literature on the relationship between property rights integrity and tenure security by identifying different sources of tenure insecurity
column8: emphasizing the effect of property rights integrity on long-term tenure security
column9:
and taking into account the potential endogeneity problem.

";"Zhou
column10: Yuepeng

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/525953;"Unpacking systemic innovation capacity as strategic ambidexterity : How projects dynamically configure capabilities for agricultural innovation";"";"Problems in agriculture and land use are increasingly recognised as complex
column3: operating at multiple levels (field to global value chains) and involving social
column4: economic
column5: institutional
column6: and technological change. This has implications for how projects navigate complexity to achieve impact. However
column7: few studies have systematically evaluated how project actors engage with other actors to configure capabilities and resources across multiple levels in agricultural innovation systems (AIS)
column8: from the individual to the network
column9: to mobilise and build systemic innovation capacity. An analytical framework conceptualising the nested configuration of capabilities at multiple levels in the AIS is applied to two projects that successfully tackled agricultural and land management problems of differing complexity: (i) improving lamb survival; and (ii) sustainable land management in New Zealand. Findings indicate that innovation capacity constitutes project actors interacting with other AIS actors to configure capabilities and resources at different levels of the AIS in order to leverage positive project path dependencies and break path dependencies that are created by existing and historical capability configurations. Project actors also balance exploiting existing innovation capabilities
column10: as well as using adaptive capability for exploring and creating new capability configurations to respond to emerging circumstances. This implies that projects should have strategic ambidexterity in terms of how they combine exploiting existing and exploring new networks to access
column11: combine
column12: create
column13: or disconnect certain capabilities to address ‘capability voids’ in AIS. This requires support to projects to constantly scrutinise
column14: through reflexive monitoring by dedicated facilitators
column15: specific agriculture and land use policies connected to major sustainable development models (e.g. climate smart agriculture
column16: urban farming
column17: smart farming). The can help assess whether the AIS provides the right mix of capabilities and whether this is adequately supported by innovation policy
column18: to realize transformative policy objectives.";"Turner

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/524118;"Land use change impacts on floods at the catchment scale : Challenges and opportunities for future research";"";"Research gaps in understanding flood changes at the catchment scale caused by changes in forest management
column3: artificial drainage
column4: and terracing are identified. Potential strategies in addressing these gaps are proposed
column5: such as complex systems approaches to link processes across time scales
column6: long-term experiments on physical-chemical-biological process interactions
column7: and a focus on connectivity and patterns across spatial scales. It is suggested that these strategies will stimulate new research that coherently addresses the issues across hydrology
column8: soil and agricultural sciences
column9: forest engineering
column10: forest ecology
column11: and geomorphology.";"Rogger

column2:
a global model of human impact on the biodiversity of inland aquatic ecosystems";"";"

Biodiversity in freshwater ecosystems - rivers
column3: lakes and wetlands - is undergoing rapid global decline. Major drivers are land use change
column4: eutrophication
column5: hydrological disturbance
column6: climate change
column7: overexploitation and invasive species. We developed a global model for assessing the dominant human impacts on inland aquatic biodiversity. The system consists of a biodiversity model
column8: named GLOBIO-Aquatic
column9: that is embedded in the IMAGE model framework
column10: i.e. linked to models for demography
column11: economy
column12: land use changes
column13: climate change
column14: nutrient emissions
column15: a global hydrological model and a global map of water bodies. The biodiversity model is based on a recompilation of existing data
column16: thereby scaling-up from local/regional case-studies to global trends. We compared species composition in impacted lakes
column17: rivers and wetlands to that in comparable undisturbed systems. We focussed on broad categories of human-induced pressures that are relevant at the global scale. The drivers currently included are catchment land use changes and nutrient loading affecting water quality
column18: and hydrological disturbance and climate change affecting water quantity. The resulting relative mean abundance of original species is used as indicator for biodiversity intactness. For lakes
column19: we used dominance of harmful algal blooms as an additional indicator. The results show that there is a significant negative relation between biodiversity intactness and these stressors in all types of freshwater ecosystems. In heavily used catchments
column20: standing water bodies would lose about 80% of their biodiversity intactness and running waters about 70%
column21: while severe hydrological disturbance would result in losses of about 80% in running waters and more than 50% in floodplain wetlands. As an illustration
column22: an analysis using the OECD 'baseline scenario' shows a considerable decline of the biodiversity intactness in still existing water bodies in 2000
column23: especially in temperate and subtropical regions
column24: and a further decline especially in tropical regions in 2050. Historical loss of wetland areas is not yet included in these results. The model may inform policy makers at the global level in what regions aquatic biodiversity will be affected most and by what causes
column25:
and allows for scenario analysis to evaluate policy options.

";"Janse

column1: NARCIS:wur:oai:library.wur.nl:wurpubs/369293;"Are farm households' renting and migration decisions inter-related in rural China?";"";"Economic reforms in rural China have stimulated the development of land and labour markets. The increasing importance of these two markets suggests that they might be closely inter-related
column2: but proper statistical tests are lacking. This paper examines the factors that determine the participation of farm households in land renting and migration
column3: and investigates whether participation in land renting and migration influence each other
column4: using a seemingly unrelated bivariate probit regression. Data from a household survey held in 2000 in three villages in the north-east of the Jiangxi Province were used to estimate the land renting and migration equations. Household characteristics
column5: fixed factors
column6: household land and labour endowments
column7: institutional factors
column8: and land and labour prices were used as explanatory variables in both equations. We found that the error terms of the land renting equation and the migration equation were strongly correlated
column9: confirming that there is a negative relationship between land renting and migration";"Feng
column10: S.

column2: state making and agrarian transformation in post-apartheid South Africa";"";"Revisiting South Africa's land and agrarian questions / Grasian Mkodzongi and Femke Brandt -- Broadening conceptions of democracy and citizenship : the subaltern histories of rural resistance in Mpondoland and Marikana / Sarah Bruchhausen and Camalita Naicker -- From material to cultural : historiographic approaches to the Eastern Cape's agrarian past / Elene Cloete -- South Africa's dangerous game : re-configuring power and belonging on Karoo trophy-hunting farms / Femke Brandt -- Gendered nationhood and the land question in South Africa 20 years after democracy / Kezia Batisai -- Farm worker 'development' agendas : what does sports have to do with it? / Tarminder Kaur -- Intricacies of game farming and outstanding land restitution claims in the Gongolo area of Kwazulu-Natal
column3: South Africa / Tariro Kamuti -- Inclusive business models in South African land restitution : great expectations and ambiguous outcomes explored / Nerhene Davis -- 'We won't have Zim-style land grabs' : what can South Africa learn from Zimbabwe's fast-track land reforms? / Grasian Mkodzongi -- Khoisan revivalism and land question in post-apartheid South Africa / Chizuko Sato -- The land-reform programme and its contribution to the livelihoods of poor people / Fani Ncapayi -- 'Disrupting spatial legacies' : dismantled game farms as success stories of land reform? / Mnqobi Ngubane -- Agency and state planning in South Africa's land-reform process / Femke Brandt and Grasian Mkodzongi.

column1: Abstract: ""Land Reform Revisited' engages with contemporary debates on land reform and agrarian transformation in South Africa. The volume offers insights into post-apartheid transformation dynamics through the lens of agency and state making. The chapters written by emerging scholars are based on extensive qualitative research and their analysis highlights the ways in which people negotiate and contest land reform realities and politics. By focusing on the diverse meanings of land and competing interpretations of what constitutes success and failure in land reform Brandt and Mkodzongi insist on looking beyond the productivity discourses guiding research and policy making in the field towards an informed view from below"".";"Brandt

column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/2d349fc0-a92d-4c55-bf60-70e47546050e;"Using a touch table to support participatory land use planning";"";"Designing land use plans for areas with multiple stakeholders is becoming an increasingly complex task. This paper presents a method to interactively develop land use plans with multiple stakeholders and conflicting objectives. In this method
column2: spatial information plays a central role. Maps are used to communicate and exchange knowledge among policy-makers and stakeholders. This is done through a series of interconnected workshops
column3: where interaction between stakeholders is prompted through the use of maps
column4: decision support tools and an instrument called the 'touch table'. The touch table is a touch-enabled screen
column5: which is used to support stakeholder collaboration through common visualization and spatial information handling. Three types of workshops with different map use are distinguished: Design (map as design language)
column6: Analysis (map as research model) and Negotiation (map as decision agenda). The main goal of a Design workshop is to identify problems concerning the planning of an area using spatial information to prompt knowledge exchange. Participants are invited to explore and develop land use plans using three reference plans as a defined playing field. With the help of simple drawing tools users can provide feedback digitally and design alternative plans by drawing polygons in free-form mode and subsequently allocating land use classes. In an Analysis workshop
column7: participants are invited to evaluate and adjust any of the reference plans. To create a new plan
column8: the reference plans are used as the canvas
column9: on which participants can 'paint' land use changes. As users 'paint' new land uses on parcels
column10: feedback on suitability is provided dynamically on the touch table. The main goal of a Negotiation workshop is to reach a land use plan that increases both the objective values of the stakeholders and the total value of a reference plan. Functionality is incorporated into the touch table to help participants suggest land use changes. Multi-Criteria Analysis (MCA) is used to provide feedback on the relative qualities of the plan compared to the reference situation. A multi-user interface allows participants to display on the map the parcels that are both best and worst suited for their own specific interests. Having 'negotiable' parcels shown on the map
column11: users can trade their 'bad' parcels with each other and proceed to paint a new 'negotiated' plan. By making these trades-offs explicit
column12: users are prompted to work as a team in a collaborative environment to reach a plan that is the best possible for all. We have tested our approach during Design
column13: Analysis and Negotiation workshops with stakeholders of the Bodegraven polder in the Netherlands. Land use must be reallocated in Bodegraven to meet new water level conditions. Surveys conducted revealed the participants' preference for the touch table over printed maps. They liked especially the possibilities to choose and combine background maps
column14: navigate across the area
column15: see what others do and add qualifications to a plan. The touch table increased their awareness of new aspects of the area's problems. Participants thought it can stimulate significantly the discussions and considered it to be most suitable for government representatives.";"Arciniegas Lopez
column16: G.A.

column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/775c0bb1-881b-4af9-bed1-6e8bc25edf9a;"Land use mediates riverine nitrogen export under the dominant influence of human activities";"";"Riverine nitrogen (N) export is a crucial process that links upstream and downstream ecosystems and coastal zones. However
column2: the driving forces of riverine N export that is closely related to water N pollution are still not well understood. In this study
column3: we used a mass balance approach to quantify the sources of N discharge and analyzed the effect of land use composition on riverine N export
column4: taking Zhejiang Province
column5: China as a case study. We found that the total reactive N discharge to rivers in Zhejiang increased from 0.22 to 0.26 Tg yr-1 from 2000 to 2015. At the watershed scale
column6: our estimate of N export agrees well with the monitored riverine N concentration in the eight major watersheds in Zhejiang. Direct discharge of domestic wastewater and effluents from wastewater treatment plants are dominant sources of riverine N export
column7: followed by agricultural non-point sources. Although riverine N export increases with the increasing proportion of urban and agricultural land uses
column8: we did not find any relationship between land use change and changes in riverine N export. This suggests that the dominant factor affecting riverine N export should be human activities (e.g. wastewater discharge and fertilization level)
column9: while land use only mediates riverine N export.";"Chen

column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/a295f66b-d9f5-4dfd-ac7a-4a944f280f0a;"Environmental cognitions mediate the causal explanation of land change";"";"Causal explanations of land change are fundamental in land system science
column2: yet existing findings are difficult to synthesize due to the imprecise terminology and the various analytical frameworks they have applied. This paper compares three existing conceptual frameworks
column3: in terms of underlying driving forces and proximate causes
column4: actors
column5: and environmental cognitions
column6: by aligning the relevant elements into a causal chain. We find that the elicitation of environmental cognitions helps in providing a detailed description of this causal chain. By synthesizing case study evidence on agricultural land change into the generalized causal chain
column7: we find that the effects of underlying driving forces on land change have been substantially mediated by environmental cognitions. Operationalizing environmental cognitions requires more efforts than regular actor-based studies
column8: but a proper understanding of its mediating role should be accounted for in local scale studies and is essential for human-centred policy design.";"Yu

column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/49530830-e939-4b0e-a3ec-f7633afc3c7e;"Scenario analysis for integrated water resources management under future land use change in the Urmia Lake region
column2: Iran";"";"Arid and semi-arid regions are particularly vulnerable to global environmental change because of their fragile climatic conditions. The rapid development of land use is expected to affect aquatic ecosystems in these regions. In this study
column3: we focused on how land use change affects the stream flow and inflow to Urmia Lake in the Mordagh Chay basin
column4: Iran. This case-study exemplifies dynamics found across a much larger region. We mapped changes in land use between 1993–2015 using satellite imagery and modeled future changes using the Dyna-CLUE model. We projected future land use change until 2030 under four scenarios: continuing of the current trend of water use
column5: 40% water withdrawal reduction
column6: and two other scenarios with 40% water withdrawal reduction and improvements of irrigation efficiency up to 50% and 85%. Between 1993–2015
column7: 21% of the study area changed to orchard and arable land mostly at the cost of rangeland. However
column8: upon reduction of water withdrawal our analyses showed that garden must decrease between 27% and 40%. Rainfed cropland is projected to experience a major increase in all scenarios
column9: especially in the case of reduced water withdrawal
column10: where it will increase by 217%. In order to achieve sustainable water resources management land use plays a major role and leads to different land use futures in this type of semi-arid regions.";"Shirmohammadi Chelan

column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/f1155066-d100-4871-ad0c-18d9381cb01d;"The Impact of Accounting for Future Wood Production in Global Vertebrate Biodiversity Assessments";"";"Forests are among the most species rich habitats and the way they are managed influences their capacity to protect biodiversity. To fulfill increasing wood demands in the future
column2: planted and non-planted wood production will need to expand. While biodiversity assessments usually focus on the impacts of deforestation
column3: the effects of wood harvest are mostly not considered
column4: especially not in a spatially explicit manner. We present here a global approach to refine the representation of forest management through allocating future wood production to planted and non-planted forests. Wood production
column5: following wood consumption projections of three Shared Socioeconomic Pathways
column6: was allocated using likelihood maps for planted and production forests. On a global scale
column7: plantations for wood production were projected to increase by 45–65% and harvested area in non-planted forests by 1–17%. The biodiversity impacts of changes in wood production patterns were estimated by applying two commonly used indicators: (1) changes in species richness and (2) changes in habitat-suitable ranges of single species. The impact was analyzed using forest cover changes as reference. Our results show that
column8: although forest cover changes have the largest impact on biodiversity
column9: changes in wood production also have a significant effect. The magnitude of impacts caused by changes of wood production substantially differs by region and taxa. Given the importance of forest production changes in net negative emission pathways
column10: more focus should be put on assessing the effects of future changes in wood production patterns as part of overall land use change impacts.";"Schulze
column11: Katharina

column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/9617dc66-d839-4f0b-8042-957049b1d486;"What constraints the expansion of urban agriculture in Benin?";"";"Propelled by rapid urbanization
column2: city administrations in low-and middle-income countries face a raft of challenges to secure food and nutrition for its poor urban dwellers. Urban agriculture (UA) seems a viable intervention to address urban food insecurity
column3: however
column4: experience has shown that urban gardens do not expand at the expected rate. Tackling this issue requires a deeper understanding of the main constraints that block UA expansion. Benin is not an exception; the country witnesses a breathtaking growth of its main cities that is in synchronization with a mounting food insecurity. Our research aims
column5: therefore
column6: to identify the main constraints for the expansion of UA in Benin
column7: and adopt a three-pronged approach combined with a systematic literature review
column8: a survey held among experienced urban gardeners
column9: and in-depth interviews with stakeholders. Altogether
column10: the synthesis shows a predominance of five main constraints: lack of land and tenure insecurity
column11: insufficient government support
column12: restricted market access
column13: limited access to productive factors
column14: and inequality issues. Specifically
column15: while the review showed that most barriers are linked and could be tackled together
column16: the survey indicated a political unwillingness which in our in-depth interviews is explained by the unperceived benefits of investing in UA and the lack of enforcement of urban development plans. We suggest that Beninese authorities and academics move in synchronization where the former coordinates the planning of urban gardens and the latter provides evidence to trigger public and private investments in UA. The findings could be the basis for further research on UA in West Africa and the wider continent.";"Houessou
column17: Mawuna Donald

column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/4f7f866f-b27e-46bf-b70b-62bd794ce2a4;"Participatory scenario development to address potential impacts of land use change: An example from the Italian alps";"";"Changes to land use such as the removal of natural vegetation and expansion of urban areas can result in degradation of the landscape and an increase in hydro-meteorological risk. This has led to higher interest by decision-makers and scientists in the future consequences of these drivers. Scenario development can be a useful tool for addressing the high uncertainty regarding modeling future land use changes. Scenarios are not exact forecasts
column2: but images of plausible futures. When studying future land dynamics
column3: emphasis should be given to areas experiencing high rates of socioeconomic change. We have focused on the eastern Italian Alps
column4: which face increasing pressure from tourism development. Identified drivers of local land use change are mostly external and difficult to quantify. This area
column5: characterized by a traditional Alpine landscape
column6: is subject to high levels of hydro-meteorological risk
column7: another reason to study potential future land use changes. We tested a scenario generation method based on existing decisions and assumptions about future tourism development. We aimed to develop a framework leading to plausible scenarios that can overcome data inaccessibility and address external drivers. We combined qualitative methods
column8: such as stakeholder interviews and cognitive mapping
column9: with geospatial methods
column10: such as geographic information systems
column11: geostatistics
column12: and environmental modeling. We involved stakeholders from the beginning to support the steps of generating data
column13: understanding the system of land use change
column14: and developing a land use change model for scenario development. In this way
column15: we generated spatio-temporal scenarios that can assist future spatial planning and improve preparedness for possible undesirable development.";"Malek
column16: Žiga

column1: NARCIS:rug:oai:pure.rug.nl:publications/d5ef745b-3b53-451e-9774-f838e3858665;"Soil organic matter dynamics after the conversion of arable land to pasture";"";"Conversion of arable land (maize) to pasture will affect the soil organic matter (SOM) content. Changes in the SOM content were studied using a size- and density-fractionation method and C-13 analysis. Twenty-six years of maize cropping had resulted in a depletion of carbon stored in the macro-organic fractions (>150 mu m) and an increase in the 250 mu m)
column2: light (b.d. 150 mu m) and light (b.d. 150 mu m; b.d. >1.13 g cm(-3)) in the 0- to 20-cm layer was still 40-50% lower than in the continuous pasture plots. Average half-life times calculated from C-13 analyses ranged from 7 years in the light fractions to 56 years in heavy fractions. Fractionation results and C-13 data indicated that mechanical disturbance (plowing) during maize cropping had resulted in vertical displacement of dispersed soil carbon from the 0- to 20-cm layer down to 60-80 cm. Conversion of arable land to pasture
column3: therefore
column4: not only causes a regeneration of the soil carbon content
column5: it also reduces the risk of contaminant transport by dispersed soil carbon.";"Römkens
column6: Paul F.A.M.

A close cooperation between the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) and ISO is expected to accelerate those developments. A huge task is waiting: the establishment of land rights for all: young and old
column3: male and female. Data on many millions of parcels
column4: spatial units
column5: (use-) rights
column6: persons
column7: and parties have to be collected
column8: linked
column9: maintained
column10: and published. Land Administration Systems (LAS) should be designed for maintenance of the dynamic relations between people and land. Existing land administrations require extensions: such as 3D and 4D functionality and datasets
column11: blockchain for transparent transactions
column12: generic processes and integration with remote sensing
column13: and processes to support conversion from social to legal tenure. A broad range of geospatial technologies and applications are available. They range from satellite and drone imaging and mapping
column14: to geodesy
column15: precise positioning
column16: geo‐information science
column17: cartography
column18: spatial data infrastructure
column19: and many surveying sub‐disciplines. The scientific and professional disciplines in the geospatial community design
column20: develop

column1: NARCIS:ut:oai:ris.utwente.nl:publications/403905d6-09b4-4fca-a9db-48d756b7b5db;"On the design of a modern and generic approach to land registration: The Colombia experience";"";"A significant number of undocumented people-to-land relationships exist in many countries; they constitute an important barrier to economic development
column2: especially that of rural areas. Although countries often have established procedures to register these relationships
column3: typically
column4: procedures involve outdated
column5: costly and time-consuming workflows
column6: and in many cases
column7: require workflow resources that are simply unavailable. The vital
column8: underlying technology and standards to collect and manage the required data are complex and sometimes inaccessible
column9: or if available
column10: tools do not comply with adopted (inter)national standards. If we continue down this path
column11: the registration of undocumented people-to-land relationships will take significantly more time and money than governments are willing to afford and be held responsible for. While each issue mentioned above presents a substantial challenge
column12: it is only by addressing them holistically that a significant impact can be obtained. Using the post-conflict Colombia as a pilot area and fit-for-purpose land administration as philosophy (FIG/World Bank
column13: 2014; UN Habitat/GLTN/Kadaster
column15: we have developed and tested a simplified
column16: communitybased
column17: standards-compliant methodology and supporting technology
column18: to register people-toland relationships in a fast and economically viable way. A country cannot afford to be non-compliant with the ISO’s 19152 standard
column19: which defines a reference land administration model (LADM). Its adoption
column20: however
column21: adds a whole level of complexity to existing procedures. We therefore developed a multi-level data model based on LADM
column22: in which each level is optimized for the procedural step where it is used. These steps are: data collection
column23: post-processing
column24: validation and recording. At the end of the last step the data complies fully with the standard and
column25: in the case of Colombia
column26: with the corresponding country profile. The developers of this profile made relevant observations for the development of the second edition of LADM — commented in this paper. Conventionally
column27: in countries with very traditional institutions like for example Colombia
column28: land administration data collection is carried out by specialists who use sophisticated measuring equipment and high-detail forms following a multi-purpose cadastre philosophy. We propose a multi-layer approach in which the base data on people-to-land relationships is collected first
column29: and then data associated with other land administration aspects is optionally added as part of normal government agencies operations. For the data collection
column30: we worked with Esri and Trimble and developed technology that satisfies two intrinsic objectives. The first is to create the ability to collect data that meets the requirements of the data collection data model
column31: and the second is to install the ability in landowners/rightholders and community members to collect the data themselves. Contrary to conventional point-based land surveys
column32: our data model uses polygons as the basis of surveying. In addition
column33: geometric and legal data are collected simultaneously
column34: and this includes evidence documentation. All types of people-to-land relationships are captured: formal
column35: informal
column36: customary
column37: etc. Since the community is responsible for the data collection
column38: several activities are organized to ensure data collection is carried out according to ethodological requirements. A data collection plan is devised to allow multiple survey teams (five were used in the pilot tests) to work in parallel over a period of a week to cover a complete administrative area. Since every landowner surveys her/his own land
column39: boundaries between neighbouring parcels are collected twice. In practice
column40: during a survey either neighbour aims to approximate the boundary by staying on her/his own property and maximising land extent
column41: which may lead to little intersection between the surveyed baoundaries. Also
column42: points where multiple people-toland relationships converge are surveyed multiple times. To generate the dataset that complies with the post-processing data model
column43: we developed a customized library of functions that are used to transform surveyed data into topologically correct representations of real-world land parcels in a semi-automated way. Traditionally
column44: the quality of the surveyed data is determined only by the accuracy of the observations made. Since we do not follow such a classical approach
column45: we included an additional validation step that is executed in a public forum to which the community is invited by the local authorities to corroborate the results of the post-processing. During this forum event
column46: neighbour landowners or right-holders check and approve their shared boundary with a digital signature. This procedure uses a big screen so that results are openly presented for the whole community to witness and comment on
column47: making the procedure fully transparent. Authorities also use this forum to check and validate identities
column48: neighbouring relationships and supporting evidence. The last step in the process leads to the recording of different types of people-to-land relationship in the official government systems. This step includes the legal analysis of the evidence of rights provided by the citizens and the evidence existing in government information systems to determine the official type of right for each recorded relationship. Some of the peopleto-land relationships can be immediately formalized and lead to land titles. Others fall into different categories of rights that require some kind of follow-up procedure
column49: but they can potentially lead to a title also.";"Morales Guarin
column50: J.M.

column1: NARCIS:rug:oai:pure.rug.nl:publications/c00222c0-21d1-4cc5-85e2-915a2b64ccdf;"Compensation for Expropriated Community Farmland in Nigeria: An In-Depth Analysis of the Laws and Practices Related to Land Expropriation for the Lekki Free Trade Zone in Lagos";"";"In Nigeria
column2: the recurring impoverishment and other negative socioeconomic impacts endured by landholders affected by expropriation are well-documented and call into question the Land Use Act's (LUA) effectiveness in protecting local land rights. The World Bank's Land Governance Assessment Framework found that
column3: in Nigeria
column4: ""a large number of acquisitions occurs without prompt and adequate compensation
column5: thus leaving those losing land worse off
column6: with no mechanism for independent appeal even though the land is often not utilized for a public purpose"". Such negative outcomes may be due to a number of factors
column7: including corruption
column8: limited capacity
column9: and insufficient financing as well as Nigeria's weak legal framework. According to a recent study of compensation procedures established in national laws of 50 countries
column10: Nigeria's compensation procedure lags behind many of the countries assessed because the LUA mostly fails to adopt international standards on the valuation of compensation. This article examines Nigerian expropriation and compensation procedures in more detail by combining both an in-depth legal analysis of Nigeria's expropriation laws as well as survey and qualitative research that indicates
column11: to some extent
column12: how expropriation laws function in practice in Nigeria. Based on our legal assessment
column13: surveys
column14: and interviews with both government and private sector officials involved in the LFTZ
column15: we found that the Nigerian government failed to comply with international standards on expropriation and compensation
column16: both in terms of its laws and its practices in the LFTZ case. This article expands our conference paper written for the UN Economic Commission of Africa Conference on Land Policy in Africa
column17: which took place in Addis Ababa
column18: Ethiopia in November of 2017. Under Nigeria's LUA
column19: affected landholders are not granted the right to participate in expropriation and compensation decision- making or otherwise be consulted on matters affecting their land and livelihoods. In 2004
column20: the LUA enabled the Lagos State government to set aside 16
column21: 500 hectares of expropriated agricultural land from Lagos coastal communities to develop the Lekki Free Trade Zone (LFTZ). Following the expropriation
column22: the Lagos State Government (LSG) and Lekki Worldwide Investment Limited signed a Memorandum of Understand (MOU) with nine affected communities in 2007. The MOU is a legally binding document that promises compensation
column23: alternative land
column24: jobs
column25: healthcare
column26: and educational opportunities to the communities affected by expropriation. However
column27: our research suggests that the MOU has not been fully honored. According to a survey of 140 affected households conducted in August 2017
column28: the government still had not paid sufficient compensation to all affected communities or had not yet provided them with suitable alternative land
column29: jobs
column30: equity shares and other entitlements promised by the MOU. While there are several reasons why the MOU has not been honored
column31: this article mainly focuses on the failure of the LUA to establish binding obligations on government officials to compensation
column32: resettle
column33: and reconstruct the livelihoods of affected landholders. This article argues that the LUA must be reformed so that
column34: whenever land is expropriated for development projects
column35: the government and private sector entities (i.e.
column36: acquiring bodies) have a legal obligation to provide sufficient and prompt compensation
column37: alternative land
column38: jobs
column39: equity shares
column40: and other entitlements to affected landholders. Moreover
column41: the LUA should obligate the government and acquiring bodies to follow a transparent and participatory process when expropriating land and compensating communities so that
column42: if properly enforced
column43: the reformed LUA can mitigate the risks commonly associated with expropriation
column44: including landholder impoverishment
column45: displacement
column46: food insecurity
column47: and conflict.";"Tagliarino
column48: Nicholas K.

column1: NARCIS:rug:oai:pure.rug.nl:publications/f1d457e0-9c6c-4259-a639-1ebf1894ed2a;"Analyses of Land Cover Change Trajectories Leading to Tropical Forest Loss: Illustrated for the West Kutai and Mahakam Ulu Districts
column3: Indonesia";"";"In Indonesia
column4: land cover change for agriculture and mining is threatening tropical forests
column5: biodiversity and ecosystem services. However
column6: land cover change is highly dynamic and complex and varies over time and space. In this study
column7: we combined Landsat-based land cover (change) mapping
column8: pixel-to-pixel cross tabulations and expert knowledge to analyze land cover change and forest loss in the West Kutai and Mahakam Ulu districts in East Kalimantan from 1990-2009. We found that about one-third of the study area changed in 1990-2009 and that the different types of land cover changes in the study area increased and involved more diverse and characteristic trajectories in 2000-2009
column9: compared to 1990-2000. Degradation to more open forest types was dominant
column10: and forest was mostly lost due to trajectories that involved deforestation to grasslands and shrubs (similar to 17%)
column11: and to a lesser extent due to trajectories from forest to mining and agriculture (11%). Trajectories from forest to small-scale mixed cropland and smallholder rubber occurred more frequently than trajectories to large-scale oil palm or pulpwood plantations; however
column12: the latter increased over time. About 11% of total land cover change involved multiple-step trajectories and thus intermediate land cover types. The combined trajectory analysis in this paper thus contributes to a more comprehensive analysis of land cover change and the drivers of forest loss
column13: which is essential to improve future land cover projections and to support spatial planning.";"van der Laan
column14: Carina

column1: NARCIS:rug:oai:pure.rug.nl:publications/92651d6c-6bb0-4089-9d23-cde9c0ba816a;"Reflections on How State–Civil Society Collaborations Play out in the Context of Land Grabbing in Argentina";"";"We examine collaborations between the state and civil society in the context of land grabbing in Argentina. Land grabbing provokes many governance challenges
column2: which generate new social arrangements. The incentives for
column3: limitations to
column4: and contradictions inherent in these collaborations are examined. We particularly explore how the collaborations between the provincial government of Santiago del Estero and non-government organizations (NGOs) played out. This province has experienced many land grabs
column5: especially for agriculture and livestock production. In response to protest and political pressure
column6: two provincial agencies were established to assist communities in relation to land tenure issues (at different stages). Even though many scholars consider state–civil society collaborations to be introduced by nation states only to gain and maintain political power
column7: we show how rural communities are actually supported by these initiatives. By empowering rural populations
column8: active NGOs can make a difference to how the negative implications of land grabbing are addressed. However
column9: NGOs and government agencies are constrained by global forces
column10: local political power plays
column11: and stakeholder struggles.";"Busscher
column12: Nienke

column1: NARCIS:eur:oai:repub.eur.nl:135205;"Placing Sustainability: Geo-Historical Entanglements of Grassroots Innovations and Place-Making Politics in Taiwan";"";"Grassroots innovations
column2: understood as bottom-up experiments on more socio-ecologically sound practices
column3: have been a primary focus in civic-oriented studies on transformative pathways to sustainability. However
column4: grassroots innovation studies often adopt a socio-technical systemic approach
column5: whereby grassroots actors’ aspirations
column6: mobilization efforts
column7: and visions beyond the scope of certain socio-technical transitions are largely left off. This thesis proposes a place-centered enabling approach that foregrounds site-specific needs and place-based politics to better capture the nature and transformative potential of grassroots innovations. It first reconceptualizes a grassroots niche as ‘a hybrid space’ grounded in socio-spatial dynamics and networked politics and mixed with elements of incumbent socio-technical regimes. Drawing inspiration from political ecology and human geography
column8: it then recasts grassroots innovations as grassroots place-making actions and analytically focuses on three constituents—the development history of the host community
column9: outstanding place-framings
column10: and internal and/or external place-making politics—to investigate a grassroots innovation in relation to the socio-spatial transformation and the underlying politico-economic structure experienced by a community. Empirically
column11: this research draws on evidence from three cases of energy and agri-food grassroots innovations in Taiwan that address important problems emerging from the country’s capitalist development
column12: including the violation of indigenous rights
column13: resource grabbing
column14: and industrial pollution. Evidence was built through a comprehensive data collection
column15: in-depth interviews
column16: and participant observation over the course of 11 months in 2016 and 2017
column17: supplemented by three annual post-fieldwork visits.

column1: The research shows that the formation of a grassroots innovation is often motivated by the geo-historical processes that communities co-evolve with and may seek to change in line with other defensive and/or innovative actions. Moreover
column2: its development can be subject to structural lock-ins underlying site-specific concerns that also constrain systemic solutions. Overlooking unmet site-specific needs and ends can lead to problematic gaps in knowledge production for policymaking
column3: which can unintentionally consolidate the injustice a community has faced. With these findings
column4: the research contributes to the debate of transformative pathways to sustainability by joining the call for a geographical and critical turn in sustainability transitions research
column5: thereby facilitating dialogues between grassroots innovation studies and critical studies for radical change. It enriches the meaning of ‘sustainability’ by situating it in the context of a (former) developmental state in East Asia
column6: and expands the scope from socio-technical transitions to socio-spatial and structural transformations from a grounded
column7: bottom-up perspective
column8: which I argue
column9: is vital to reach a real ‘win-win’ balance between ‘sustainable’ community development and ‘sustainable’ socio-technical transitions.";"Lai

column1: NARCIS:vu:oai:research.vu.nl:publications/c6df6af4-1def-46fa-8cc0-2052067e3dc9;"Telecoupled environmental impacts of current and alternative Western diets";"";"Low-meat and no-meat diets are increasingly acknowledged as sustainable alternatives to current Western food consumption patterns. Concerns for the environment
column2: individual health or animal welfare are raising consumers’ willingness to adopt such diets. Dietary shifts in Western countries may modify the way human-environment systems interact over distances
column3: primarily as a result of existing trade flows in food products. Global studies have focused on the amount of water
column4: land
column5: and CO2 emissions embodied in plant-based versus animal-based proteins
column6: but the potential of alternative diets to shift the location of environmental impacts has not yet been investigated. We build on footprint and trade-based analyses to compare the magnitude and spatial allocation of the impacts of six diets of consumers in the United States of America (USA). We used data on declared diets as well as a stylized average diet and a recent dietary guideline integrating health and environmental targets. We demonstrate that low-meat and no-meat diets have a lower demand for land and utilize more crops with natural nitrogen fixation potential
column7: yet also rely more widely on pollinator abundance and diversity
column8: and can increase impacts on freshwater ecosystems in some countries. We recommend that governments carefully consider the local impacts of the alternative diets they promote
column9: and minimize trade-offs between the global and local consequences of dietary shifts through regulation or incentives.";"Laroche
column10: Perrine C.S.J.

column1: NARCIS:ut:oai:ris.utwente.nl:publications/bcdc2f6c-981a-4210-93f8-9af1f9559bc5;"Cross-cutting challenges to innovation in land tenure documentation";"";"Since around 2011 pilot projects to innovate land tenure documentation are being implemented in various countries in the global south in order to address the shortcomings of formal land registration. A longer-term question
column3: is how these innovations relate in the longer run to existing institutional arrangements of land governance in the respective context of implementation. Guided by this more general question
column4: we discuss in this paper first the characteristics for 6 of these approaches. And second
column5: we discuss four closely related challenges identified through a thematic analysis from interview transcripts with representatives of the initiatives. Regarding characteristics
column6: we find a basic commonality of the initiatives is the general approach to tenure documentation through community based digital data capture
column7: in many cases via mobile applications
column8: and the acknowledgment of the plurality of land tenure regimes
column9: which are often not accounted for in statutory land tenure registration laws and/or administrative procedures and practices. Looking at the initiatives in more detail a number of differences become apparent in terms of financing mechanisms and organizational characteristics
column10: as well as application domains. We identify four challenges in the process of implementation. One is the need to strike a balance between inclusion of diverse land tenures
column11: on one hand
column12: and necessary adjustments to existing institutional norms and regulations in land governance. A second pertains to questions of purpose and longer-term goals as implementation requires a fair amount of flexibility in practice. The third challenge relates to the question of the legitimacy of both collected digital data and the paper documents that are being issued. And finally
column13: on the side of digital data production
column14: a longer-term challenge pertains to finding an good balance between transparency and openness
column15: on one hand
column16: and protection of people's land data
column17: on the other. Based on these challenges
column18: we discuss directions for future implementation
column19: evaluation and research.";"Lengoiboni
column20: M.

column2: Land Data and User Needs: A Socio-Technical Assessment in Rwanda";"";"Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) are emerging as a tool for alternative land tenure data acquisition. Even though UAS appear to represent a promising technology
column3: it remains unclear to what extent they match the needs of communities and governments in the land sector. This paper responds to this question by undertaking a socio-technical study in Rwanda
column4: aiming to determine the match between stakeholders' needs and the characteristics of the UAS data acquisition workflow and its final products as valuable spatial data for land administration and spatial planning. A needs assessment enabled the expression of a range of land information needs across multiple levels and stakeholder sectors. Next to the social study
column5: three different UAS were flown to test not only the quality of data but the possibilities of the use of this technology within the current institutional environment. A priority list of needs for cadastral and non-cadastral information as well as insights into operational challenges and data quality measures of UAS-based data products are presented. It can be concluded that UAS can have a significant contribution to match most of the prioritized needs in Rwanda. However
column6: the results also reveal that structural and capacity conditions currently undermine this potential.";"Stöcker

column1: NARCIS:ut:oai:ris.utwente.nl:publications/0f993ce0-215e-4d85-a95d-0bee96fe2b6b;"Attributing Changes in Streamflow to Land Use and Climate Change for 472 Catchments in Australia and the United States";"";"A data-based method to distinguish climate and land use change impacts on streamflow has been previously developed and needs further evaluation through a large sample study. This study aims to apply the method to a large sample set of 472 catchments in the United States and Australia. The method calculates the water and energy budget of a catchment which can be translated to climate and land use induced changes in streamflow between two periods: a pre-change and post-change period. Several geographical characteristics (e.g.
column3: average catchment slope
column4: historical land use) were considered for the interpretation of the results. The results show that in general as expected
column5: an increase of the annual discharge is caused by deforestation and a wetter climate
column6: and a decrease of the annual discharge is caused by afforestation and a drier climate. In addition
column7: changes in streamflow of American catchments are likely caused by a wetter climate
column8: while changes in streamflow of Australian catchments are caused by a wetter or drier climate. It can be concluded that the method performs reasonably well and that the results are best explained by the location of the catchment
column9: the aridity index and historical land use.";"Booij

column1: NARCIS:ut:oai:ris.utwente.nl:publications/f7380f1e-5e13-436f-a3f9-a39a417fce66;"Evaluating Resilience-Centered Development Interventions with Remote Sensing";"";"Natural disasters are projected to increase in number and severity
column2: in part due to climate change. At the same time a growing number of disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation measures are being implemented by governmental and non-governmental organizations
column3: and substantial post-disaster donations are frequently pledged. At the same time there has been increasing demand for transparency and accountability
column4: and thus evidence of those measures having a positive effect. We hypothesized that resilience-enhancing interventions should result in less damage during a hazard event
column5: or at least quicker recovery. In this study we assessed recovery over a 3 year period of seven municipalities in the central Philippines devastated by Typhoon Haiyan in 2013. We used very high resolution optical images (<1 m)
column6: and created detailed land cover and land use maps for four epochs before and after the event
column7: using a machine learning approach with extreme gradient boosting. The spatially and temporally highly variable recovery maps were then statistically related to detailed questionnaire data acquired by DEval in 2012 and 2016
column8: whose principal aim was to assess the impact of a 10 year land-planning intervention program by the German agency for technical cooperation (GIZ). The survey data allowed very detailed insights into DRR-related perspectives
column9: motivations and drivers of the affected population. To some extent they also helped to overcome the principal limitation of remote sensing
column10: which can effectively describe but not explain the reasons for differential recovery. However
column11: while a number of causal links between intervention parameters and reconstruction was found
column12: the common notion that a resilient community should recover better and more quickly could not be confirmed. The study also revealed a number of methodological limitations
column13: such as the high cost for commercial image data not matching the spatially extensive but also detailed scale of field evaluations
column14: the remote sensing analysis likely overestimating damage and thus providing incorrect recovery metrics
column15: and image data catalogues especially for more remote communities often being incomplete. Nevertheless
column16: the study provides a valuable proof of concept for the synergies resulting from an integration of socio-economic survey data and remote sensing imagery for recovery assessment.";"Kerle

column1: NARCIS:ut:oai:ris.utwente.nl:publications/7769014f-66e0-424f-8554-83ec47f13ec0;"Innovating Along the Continuum of Land Rights Recognition: Meridia’s “Documentation Packages” for Ghana";"";"Documentation of land rights can ensure tenure security and facilitate smooth land transactions
column2: but in most countries of the global south this has been difficult to achieve. These difficulties are related to the high transaction cost
column3: long transaction times
column4: and procedural rigidity of land registration processes. In response to these problems
column5: innovative approaches of tenure documentation have been conceived at a global level and are being promoted in many countries of the global south. Little is known yet about how such innovative land tenure documentation approaches unfold in various contexts and to what effect. The implementation of innovative approaches is challenging
column6: due to the legal pluralistic nature of land governance and administrative hybridity in many countries of the global south
column7: including the West African region. This qualitative study explores how Meridia
column8: a small for-profit company
column9: develops innovative approaches to register land rights in the form of “documentation packages” within the existing institutional setting of Ghana. In the paper
column10: we describe both the processes of preparing the documentation packages and respective actors involved
column11: as well as the nature of encounters between innovative interventions and existing institutions. Meridia develops specific products in response to both the regional diversity of land tenure
column12: uses
column13: and market demands
column14: as well as in response to the challenges that the institutional context poses to the process of land tenure registration. As such
column15: the case illustrates how innovation evolves in step-by-step fashion through negotiations with existing land institutions. The various documentation packages developed in this manner differ in terms of cost and complexity of preparation
column16: in terms of recognition by customary and statutory institutions
column17: as well as in the usability of the issued certificates and the extent of exchangeability of associated land parcels. Therefore
column18: Meridia’s product innovation reflects the continuum of land rights
column19: but it also poses questions for future research regarding the political economy of land tenure certification and regarding the actual uses and benefits of issued certificates.";"Waah Salifu

column1: NARCIS:ut:oai:ris.utwente.nl:publications/42ccff84-83a6-45b9-9a40-724898601829;"Evaluating some major assumptions in land registration: Insights from Ghana’s context of land tenure and registration";"";"A discussion of the assumptions that underlie efforts to register land enables us to not only evaluate their validity across different contexts
column3: to further understand how the low incidences of land registration might derive from very fundamental sources outside of differences in technology and approaches of recording. Building on existing literature and previous research in Ghana
column4: this study has identified and evaluated three such assumptions
column5: namely
column6: land rights registration is desirable
column7: all land rights are registrable
column8: and access to the registration system is an administrative event. We analyzed each assumption in order to find out how they manifest in conventional approaches as well as what they imply for emerging fit-for-purpose (FFP) approaches. In the context of Ghana
column9: we find that (a) there are variations in desirability across space (urban vs. rural) and among landholders; (b) many land rights are registrable
column10: but not all
column11: unless we accept a loss in meaning; and (c) access to the registration system can be an administrative event between surveyor/surveyed
column12: but it is often a process of connecting multiple actors and practices. We conclude that close attention needs to be paid to scenarios where these fundamental assumptions fall short
column13: in order to finetune them and redirect associated implementation strategies";"Abubakari
